But I agree with other reviewers below. The food kind of tasted metallic. I got the Hong Kong style seafood chow mein and chinese broccoli with oyster sauce. The noodles in the chow mein were fine, but the seafood tasted like it was old. And there was a lot of bean sprouts in it for filler. The chinese broccoli was fine, but I think you have to be a moron to mess that up.
author: Kerry K.

description:
I just moved out of the Nob Hill/Russian Hill I'm-not-sure-which-neighborhood-this-block-really-is area, and this (along with Bob's Donuts), is what I already miss most.

Sun Kwong is FANTASTIC for either dine in or take out (and much better than the place with the softball-sized potstickers across the street).

PRICE: Can not be beat.  Large, delicious portions for insanely low prices.  Cash only is not uber-convenient, but the low price is worth the trade-off of convenience.  My boyfriend and I could order an appetizer + 3 entrees and not cross $20.  Insane.

SERVICE:  For both take-out and dine-in, I have had great experiences.  The woman who is the owner/host recognized me after going a few times and was always very friendly.  When I picked up for take-out, I was always offered tea ... and often times, when I dined in, I would get soup + tea on the house.  

DECOR: This place is not known for its extravagant or lush interior.  The focus on good, inexpensive food, and the decor is quite sparse.  I enjoy dining in there but can see why it's more of a take-out place.

FAVORITE DISHES:  Anything I've tried has been good.  A few favorites: pot stickers, beef w/ broccoli chow mein, salt & pepper pork, bbq pork with veggies, curry chicken chow mein.  Fried rice and won ton soup also solid.

OVERALL: LOVE this place...and wish it had another location in NOPA/Western Addition. :)

(Note that it's closed on Sundays, which I would tend to forget.)
author: Kathleen H.

description: Best hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaruant around. Good authetic Cantonese food with some of the all time favorites similar to growng up in Chinatown in the 70's, most notably their Hung Tao Yee Foo Won Ton, which  has a good thick broth small chunks of meat, just as I remember back in the day.  Their chow fun/mein and rice plates are all good as well.  Its a place where all the contractors and mailmen come to eat...and they know all the good places. Adding to the ambiance are the sounds and sights of the Hyde Street cable cars rolling by..."Only In San Francisco!".  Even though it's a no frills hole-in-the-wall, it is a clean place. Good food at good prices.
author: Stanley H.

description:
Sun Kwong was a nice drunk treat. I think what I ordered was the standard meal for Americanized diners (Combo A consisting of an egg roll, pork chow mein and sweet and sour pork) and it was okay. It was no Panda Express, but it was okay.

There were other Chinese diners there so I'll bet there are some really great authentic dishes there you just need to know what to get.

Some white guys told us we should try U-Lee next. Should have known not to trust them! In the epic battle between the two, Sun Kwong comes out on top. (See U-Lee review.)

All in all a very mediocre place to eat but I'd gladly eat here again for fast, cheap food, especially if I'm drunk. 


QUESTION (4/9/13):
Has anyone else who gave this place mediocre reviews get harassing "compliments" from this guy?
http://www.yelp.ca/user_details?userid=5ouztxdsa-PW_hWYx-oTfQ

Really hope he isn't affiliated with Sun Kwong. He told me I have a fat face, won't find a husband, and some other lewd and random things. All that from my profile picture and review about Sun Kwong. Yeesh.
author: K C.

description:
I have been going to Sun Kwong for most of my life. If you want good, authentic Chinese food at a cheap price, this is where it's at! You can go there with your whole family and some friends, eat tons of food, have leftovers, and still not break the bank! 

Here are some family favorites..
~ gin du spare ribs
~ beef stew
~ fatty pork
~ fried shrimp
~ fried tofu balls
~ beef chow fun
~ fried rice
~ black bean shrimp
~ gai lan

Okay, I could probably keep going on good food there, but those are pretty much our "go to" dishes. Plus, you always get a complimentary bowl of house soup to enjoy while you wait. The server is so sweet and knows our family. The tea is good, but we always ask for it to be hotter. 

As for the great debate between Sun Kwong and U-Lee??? I say they are not comparable! Yes, they are both Chinese restaurants, BUT my family has gone to both FOREVER,  and usually for different dishes. So, where we decide to go, usually depends on what we are in the mood for. However, if you want to base it solely on authentic Chinese food and great price, Sun Kwong is hard to compete with!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
You swore swore swore swore swore my prawns and veggies were steamed. Swore. I think they were. Not 100% sure. There was some unknown coating of something on the prawns, and to be fair, dabbing with a paper towel didn't reveal the usual oil blot. Not sure what it was, but a little suspect.

Not suspect was the price ($7), the size (a lot) and the educational opportunity (sharing with my sister chinese doesn't always mean oily mess).
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is in the middle of the neighborhood that I grew up, but I admit that the appearance scared me, for years.  After seeing numerous, positive Yelp reviews, I had to try.  I'm not afraid of "greasy spoon" eateries, but this place is very drab, slightly reminiscent of Mariposa Cafeteria (one of my favorites), without the 400 pound truck drivers.

The place is actually quite clean and your elbows don't even stick to the tabletops.  The waitress is friendly and helpful (she spoke to us in "Chinglish"), and translated the Chinese menu specials.  One order of beef tongue over rice and one order of pigs feet over rice.

The lunch menu includes a really large bowl of the "house" soup; this one was lotus root soup (just like Grandma's).  The specials were tasty, plentiful, and CHEAP ($4.50/ea)

This place is definitely a neighborhood jewel for the working class.  Lots of Chinese workers (house painters and construction workers), Muni drivers/conductors, SFPD, and DPT traffic control people (parking in the red zones!)
author: Collin W.

description:
This is my go-to neighborhood Chinese place. They're always friendly, quick, and cheap. What more do you need from a Chinese restaurant?
Always accommodating when I drop by a little late after work, which is a bonus.
author: Tash T.

description: Great food, hospitality, and service!  Plus the lady that works there is super friendly, offering water and a newspaper while I waited for my order to-go.
author: Josh F.

description: Small local 10 table Chinese restaurant. We had the curry chow fun, combination chow fun, fried rice, gourmet chicken (which is kind of like a cross between Sesame and orange chicken). The meals were excellent, although not as spicy as I had hoped. But I give them a four star for flavor and I spiced them up with the srichacha sauce on the table. It is a huge quantity of food for the amount of money. Many of the dishes are five dollars or under and can easily feed one hungry person or two normal people.
author: Larry L.

description: If you enjoy Westernized Chinese food more, then go for U-Lee, not to say it's bad, just different preferences. However, if you want to experience authentic, home-style Chinese cooking, then give this place a try, Susan won't let you down.
author: C J.

description:
I feel remiss for not writing this review sooner. This is my standard choice for the kind of Chinese mama home cooking I never had, but would have if I had a Chinese mama. This is the next best thing though. They treat me like family. 

It is dirt cheap with no decor to speak of (oh yeah there's a cheesecakey Chinese hottie calendar hanging on the wall) and a chalkboard with the same daily specials that are never erased - scallop with snow peas, pot stickers and a bunch of stuff in Chinese I can't read - imagine.  

I tend to order from the same rotating 5 or 6 favorites - cod fillet with tender greens rice plate, spare rib won ton soup with plum sauce, prawn with lobster sauce rice plate, bean curd with minced pork and tender green rice plate, tofu with mixed veggies and a tasty seafood combination clay pot. Meals always come with a big bowl of the daily house soup - anything from seaweed with egg, to barley with white fungus mushroom, sometimes a simple, wonderful, homemade chicken broth with bits of meat and carrot. It is very down home. Avoid the lunch rush from 12-2 when it is swarming with local workers and a madhouse. 

The sweet woman who runs the place with her husband always brings me the paper to read, toothpicks and fortune cookies at the end of my meal, and occasionally something special to share from their table when they sit down to a family meal and I happen to be in there. My Chinese home away from home. Never fancy, always warm and welcoming.
author: wendella a.

description: YUMMY is all I have to say for this place. Not just great bang for your buck but the customer service is excellent. We have always had a great experience and great food when coming here. ENJOY
author: Maria L.

description:
Sure it's dirty.    The menu in the window is stained with... something.    Pay this no mind.   This is good stuff.   You're rarely going to spend more than $6 for a take-out dinner and you'll plenty of value for your money.  

I've lived in this neighborhood for 6 days now and I gotten dinner here 3 times.    There will be plenty more in the future.
author: Beau G.

description: Sun Kwong is a really great neighborhood restaurant with friendly waitstaff, and I've been coming to this restaurant for years. It's cheap, authentic Chinese food, and I'll continue to be a loyal patron.
author: Storm T.

description: VERY IMPRESSED- great food, great service, authentic and healthy!
author: anthony e.

description:
Words cannot describe how much I love this place.   I don't know how long I've been going there but it's hovering around 30 years.  I moved down to LA years ago and make trips just to eat there.  

Don't expect any fancy ambience when you go.  Do expect yummy food for less than $5.  Everything is delicious and made to order.  

My family has gone there so long that they already know what we want and they get started on our noodles as soon as they spot us.  The family that runs this place is super nice and will make you feel at home.

Cops, cable car drivers and meter maids eat there so you know it's a good place to eat.
author: Cathie N.

description:
The cheapest entree here is $4.
The most expensive entree here is $6.25. 
The owners are incredibly friendly.
The portions are large, and the food is better than its price would suggest.
This place is exactly one block away from my house, and downhill to boot.

I had the seafood clay pot and was not disappointed; it didn't absolutely blow my friggin' mind, which would be all this place would need for the fifth star, but the price point and convenience factor are more than enough to ensure that I'll be back. 

I'll take Colleen L.'s advice next time and go with her second suggestion, although I'll have to either write its name down beforehand or bring one of my two Mandarin-speaking roommates. Hell, I'll even buy them dinner - I've bought beers for more than these meals cost.
author: JR H.

description:
what can i say about this place other than "Want a FULL meal for $5?"
and by FULL MEAL-i mean enough to feed you for a full day? breakfast, lunch and dinner?... yeah, that's the place!!!  theres a sweet old lady at the front, always takes care of us 

sucky thing is - i want to go there on Sundays, while i'm watching football....  but they're closed on Sundays!! honestly!! who closes on Sundays?!!??!? that just aint right
author: Ken T.

description: Good food for a great price.  Their menu is surprisingly expansive, with traditional Cantonese comfort food as well as standard Americanized Chinese fare.  Lunch specials go for $5.00 even, and offer a healthy serving size of food that will leave you satisfied.  It may not be a destination spot, but I recommend this hole-in-the-wall to anyone in the area.
author: Alan C.

description:
My roommate recommended this place to me and I thought I'd give it a try since its across the street from my house (1 star).  Its super cheap (1 star) and the food was good.  I feel like Chinese food in the city is so touch and go.  Its either too authentic for my taste, too greasy, or the meat is shady.

We got pot stickers, chicken fried rice, sweet & sour chicken, and beef & broccoli.  The pot stickers were pretty good.  Not amazing, but nothing to complain about.  Chicken fried rice was really really good.  Not too greasy and not that much chicken.  I hate it when its loaded with chicken, that might be weird.  But yeah, perfect amount of chicken.  My boyfriend got the sweet & sour chicken and he said that the chicken still had skin on it.  But he really enjoyed it.  Finally the beef with broccoli was meh.  The beef was pretty nasty.  But the broccoli was good.  

Overall I liked it and I will definitely go again!
author: Angela S.

description:
This is the restaraunt that inspired my joining the yelp community. 

The food and service are both fantastic, but the price is ridiculously cheap!



I live around the corner and foresee this being a once a week dining destination

My pallet, as you will learn if you follow my reviews does not give many restaraubts 5 stars

This is truly a uniqe combination of affordability and quality authentic Chinese
author: Mark P.

description:
Yelp needs a half dollar sign rating for the priciness of this place.

I had sun kwong beef, which appeared to be what the place was named after.  The waitress asked if I wanted it on the rice or separate.  I only initially understood "on the rice" and went for that.  In Taipei everyone eats rice separately from a bowl in their left hand, which is the way I prefer it too.  Sadly, my moment of understanding came too late.

First came a barley soup (on the house?) with a huge chunk of beef joint (oh so Chinese) sitting in the center.  That was decent.  Very little meat involved but it wasn't introduced as such.

Next, I got my main dish, your typical beef with all sorts of vegetables. It instantly fogged up my glasses.   After a while I realized that the reason was because the rice was blisteringly hot, not the food.  In Asia I scarcely remember having blazing hot rice, anywhere.  I think it might've been to warm up the food (the food on the edge of the plate was quite cold).

Nonetheless, when the waiter brought out the check, it came to $4.75!  I couldve sworn it was more on the menu, but I'm not complaining.

All in all, mediocre food, stunningly cheap, friendly service (Cantonese sadly though, I only speak Mandarin).  Also a block away from where I live.

If I can find something I can palate on a regular basis, I'll be back... The food is practically free.
author: Ben N.

description:
Perfect. This lady is so nice - one time I had a really bad cold and came in to make a takeout order and she insisted that I sit down and drink some tea.

The Mongolian beef and egg drop soup are my faves.
author: Leigh D.

description:
This China Girl is verrry picky about Chinese food. Very few dishes live up to my mom's. Well, I rediscovered this little family owned restaurant and  it has become  a Friday night habit.  My hubby, and I often order the following:

Singapore style 'curry' chow fun w/ shrimp
''pay pau tofu' - tofu mixed with scallions and bits of bbq pork, fried to perfection!
steamed Chinese broccolli w/ oyster sauce
black bean rock cod
and seafood clay pot

Everything is delicious!  Can you say 'HAPPY STOMACH'??
It's an added bonus that the waitress is sooo pleasant and remembers her customers!
author: Lorena W.

description:
I have eaten or gone to this place my entire life(25) years. It was a staple when i visited my grand parents. Its the standard by which i judge restaurant chow mien and chow fun.

A must try is the kung Tao Yee Foo Wonton, its an old school Chinatown dish that you can't find anymore, and they do it pretty darn good.

The chow Fun is beyond good, the noodle are the perfect texture of chewy and soft, oiled to perfection and cooked with beef I could eat that till I die and feel bad for doing so.

Shame there is no parking, but don't let that stop you!
author: Brian Y.

description: I haven't sampled too many of the items in this restaurant. What I have had has been delicious. I love the fact that I am offered tea when waiting on takeout.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
I've eaten at this place more times than I can count. I grew up near here and my family would order from here at least 5-7 times a month. Multiply that by 20+ years = some kind of figure I can't fathom. Now that I moved back to the 'hood, even hubby who is new to this area quickly made it one of his favorite take out places. I'm not going to lie and say this is the best Chinese food you'll ever eat, but the overall taste and price make it worthy of  4 stars for a take-out joint. The food is cooked home-style which is tasty, cheap, substantially portioned, and not too greasy. The owners (the wife is the server; the husband is the cook) are super friendly and will always offer you a cup of tea while waiting. 

I think I've eaten every thing on the menu at least ten times - maybe eleven?  - and it's an extensive menu - but these 5 are my top favorites which I order time and time again (they're all only  $5-$6 each). Generally everything is A-OK but the beef can be hit or miss:

1) Salty fish & chicken fried rice - Another yelper said they make the best one in town, and I would second that! The dish comes out with a beautiful smoky flavor filled with lightly seasoned bits of chicken and salty fish. I like that they chop up the salty fish small enough so that the whole order has a consistent flavor. Other places keep the bits bigger, but then you either get a mouthful of plain rice or a mouthful of just salty fish - ick! Here, the entire order is perfectly blended and every bite tastes as good as the next. They also add in some shredded lettuce which keeps the smoky flavor in check. An indicator of a good Cantonese restaurant is if the food has wok "mei" which = a smoky, wok essence. Hard to define, but essentially it's when the chef has cooked the food on a very high temperature wok (you should see actual flames shooting up under the wok) such that the flavors are sealed in with a slight smoky taste. Few restaurants master this, but Sun Kwong does it great on this dish.

2)  "hung toe yee fu won ton"  I don't even know what this is called in English, and it's not listed on their menu. Basically, it's a soup where the won tons are first fried, then added back into a soup made out of swirled egg, minced bbq char siu/pork and minced shrimp. It's garnished with cilantro and green onion, but I usually ask them to skip the cilantro. Overall, it looks like a red colored egg-drop soup w/ wonton. I like this dish because the wonton skins take on a different texture and get a distinct yet mildly smoky flavor when fried first. This soup is so good I once saw a group of Chinese workers come in with their own metal pots (some big enough to qualify as vats), and literally ask Sun Kwong to fill up their pots with this soup!  I must not be the only one that thinks it's good....    

3) Tomato Beef chow mein - This is a uniquely American-Cantonese (perhaps even only SF) dish. Several times I tried to order this down in LA and they didn't know what I was talking about or it came out horribly wrong. The tomato beef chow mein here is exactly like how it's supposed to be: a sweet, thin yet substantially tomato-tasting sauce. The one at Sun Kwong comes out with juicy pieces of tomato, onions, and red & green bell peppers. I typically don't order beef from here, but this is one dish that I would still order w/beef. The one across the street at U-Lee is also pretty good, but I like Sun Kwong's better. 

4) Pipa Tofu  ("pei pa dow fu") - I don't know if they list this on the English menu but it's on the Chinese one. They're braised tofu pieces shaped like Chinese lutes, hence the name. The tofu mixture has a little finely minced bbq pork (I'm guessing it's this but never asked) and some cilantro. The mixture is then molded into lute shapes, quickly fried so the outside is brown but the inside still soft & moist, then braised with a light sauce. It's a very light and delicate tasting dish (tofu doesn't have a lot of flavor by itself) but if you like fresh tofu, you'll probably like this. 

5) Steamed pork cake w/salty fish ("ham yu ju yok bang") This is a very traditional home-style Cantonese dish, the kind your grandma back in the village would make. It's probably best to eat this one there rather than take-out. The steamed ground pork mixture comes out soft and fluffy, has the right amount of spices, and with a nice layer of juice.  The salty fish piece in the center is big enough to flavor everything. As such, it's great comfort-food made especially well here, but if you've never eaten it before, you may not like it. Chinese people would think it looks great, but I've seen non-Asians shying away from this dish based on looks alone. It doesn't look gross, but it just doesn't visually resemble any kind of  known Western dish except maybe a steamed, wet meat patty surrounded by juice.  (See! I told you that it probably sounds weird!) But seriously, if you can get past the visual look, it's a really tasty dish.
author: Colleen L.

description: After walking around San Francisco for hours looking for a decent place to eat, my friends and I stumbled into this small resturant.  There was about 20 of us and yet, they managed to have us all in one long table.  We decided to do a family style meal which turned out to be amazing.  The food was good and service was fast considering the fact that we ordered about 10 dishes.  The only problem was the communication with our orders ( couldn't understand their accents ).  5 stars for good food, good service, and exeeding our expectations.
author: Andrew V.

description: My family and I have been coming here for years! It's the only restaurant I can remember going to as a child. I still order takeout  from here regularly. The food is consistently yummy, authentic, affordable, and the  lady who works here is super friendly. Hmmm...  I think I'm craving Sun Kwong now.
author: Sara B.

description:
i was walking by on my first day in the neighborhood, and something caught my eye. Can it be?

I walk in, "i'll have the beef tongue on rice please"

10 minutes later in my apartment...tongue on tongue action baby!
author: tru l.

description:
It's kind of an ugly place, and it may not be the cleaniest but then again what Chinese restaurant is?

Sun Kwong is just a couple blocks from my house and I've been eating there all my life. We used to eat there before it was called Sun Kwong. When I was little the waitress Yolanda would always sneak me extra fortune cookies. 

Even to this day when my family walks into the restaurant or calls for take out the waitress or the owner knows our order. Tomato beef chow mein, wonton, and foil wrapped chicken. 

Gourmet Carousel (on Franklin and Gough) used to make THE best salty fish chicken fried rice but for the past couple of years it seemed to go downhill. Sun Kwong who never used to make it well, now makes what I think is the best. It has a nice smokey flavor to it. Yum!

Sun Kwong may not be the best Chinese restaurant but it definitely is a neighborhood gem. U-Lee, which is directly across the street, is usually more crowded and most people like it better. But U-Lee is filled with mainly non-Asians whereas Sun Kwong normally serves Chinese families, like mine. Both are good but Sun Kwong has a more homemade authentic taste.
author: KayKay D.

description: You looking for cheap food, you should hit this spot. It got 2 stars from me cause food wasnt good, its eatable but no good. It was like those western movies when a stranger steps into a local bar everybody stops whatever they were doing. When we stood next to the door, we heard all the knifes falling on tables, every single costumer was asian.
author: Ekin G.

description: I love the hot and sour soup here.  It's actually hot AND sour.  Just about every place I've been to goes way too easy on the vinegar, leaving out the sour, and in some cases they leave out the hot as well so the flavor is just...brown.  The food is cheap and the lady that runs the place takes good care of me - we drink tea and talk about how dirty the city is while my food is being prepared for take out.
author: Victoria G.

description: Okay, the decor is a little mundane (a little?) and yeah the Specials board hasn't changed in ages (I did suggest they might want to liven it up a little) but then that keeps the touristy riff raff away or across the street, the U-Lee potstickers and Aspargas and Chicken in black bean sauce are both excellent but this is about SK so ... they have a daily special, Monday's is OxTail Stew, Tuesday is Chicken Curry with Potatoes, Wednesday is Pig Feet Stew, Thursday is 3 Mushroom Chicken and Friday is Lamb Stew with Dried Bean Curd.  For $5 you realy can't go wrong.  The proprietress is super nice, when I broke my foot she was hecka concerned and would take my order and deliver to my car when she would see me pull in front.  Nice house soup while you wait for your takeout.  I want to try the salty fish fried rice after reading that other reviewer.  Very cost effective place and they are very earnest in preparing good food at an incredibly reasonable price.  Maybe I should 5 star them but that might make it too crowded ... a neighborhood gem.
author: Terry A.

description: this is a nice little hole in the wall restaurant.. The food is very inexpensive and the staff are very friendly.. I believe that this is a family owned establishment and im all for supporting family owned businesses. I sat down and the nice lady brought me a newspaper and I ordered beef chow fun and egg rolls. The food was good and different then your run of the mill Chinese food. The egg rolls were very tasty and came with sweet and sour sauce, which I think was made from beets.
author: Bradley P.

description:
You know you are in a good place when you can get your dishes Made-To-Order. It's hard to find the right combination of rice noodles, meat and veggies outside of my own kitchen, so I'm glad that this place is so close to home.  

Sun Kwong isn't much to look at and not quite a place known for their ambiance. However, if you value a good value - this is the place to go for a quick fix if you're not sure what to do for dinner.  Their Sam See Mai Fun is one of best in the city. Chinese foodies talk about the amount of Wok-Intensity (Wok - Hei) that makes a good restaurant -  the chef definitely has that magic touch- which turns Americanized Chinese food into something quite authentic and tasty!
author: Caryn L.

description: This place feeds me at least four times a week.  Eat there.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Decent food, at pretty much the best price ever? The couple that owns this hole in the wall, have been running this restaurant for twenty-five years strong. I have so much respect for people who start their own businesses.

The waitress says the business can be slow because parking is so difficult (which I strongly agree). The customers there were CLEARLY regulars at Sun Kwong. So friendly, and sparked conversation with the waitress.

Hasd the basic fried rice fix, peppered chicken, and veggie and tofu. It was decent food, and so cheap!
author: Melissa E.

description: Five stars for Yolanda alone!  She's awesome!  She always remembers what I like to order even when I haven't been there in a while.  Large portions at low prices.  My friend and I used to go there all the time and order soup (the best hot and sour soup), potstickers, and two entrees.  We would leave FULL with leftovers and never pay more than $20 total with tip (actually, we would usually kick down a couple extra bucks for Yolanda.)  Sun Kwong is definitely a hole in the wall, but is my favorite place for good, cheap Chinese food.
author: Sara H.

description:
Oh wow!  Home cooking, Chinese style.  Huge, huge portions for dirt cheap prices all served in what looks like the owner's personal kitchen.  Most entrees are huge, good, and under $6.   One time, I dined on a 6 course family style meal with 6 people for less than $40!  And it was all really good.   It is all dished up by a mild mannered, sweet woman who is the owner.  It really feels like home when you are dining here.

Some of the things I have tried and liked are sweet and sour pork, potstickers, wonton soup, chow mein, chef's special chicken, beef with broccoli, and so on.  There are also a lot of really authentic items if you are so inclined. The chef who is the other owner will also cook up special requests.  So, if you have a favorite dish that mom used make (my mom is white as hell, so she only made bland white people Chinese-inspired food), then ask for it to be made.
author: t l.

description:
This place is a solid 3-star. The cooking is more authentic than I like although I am Cantonese. I much prefer U-Lee, which is cati-corner from this place. The clientel is predominately Asian here, which attests to its more authentic Chinese cooking. I am just too used to Americanized Chinese cooking, having been away from the Bay Area for too many years. As a kid growing up in SF, I ate all the authentic stuff, but no more. I can't believe all the stuff I ate then...

Note that I gave Sun Kwong only 3 stars because I am not a fan of too authentic, "down-home" Chinese cooking. However, someone who is, may well give them 4 or 5 stars. So my rating does NOT imply that their food is not good, just not my cup of tea.

Susan, the waitress and wife of the cook, is very friendly and courteous.
author: John C.

description: 3.5 stars.  it's hard finding good chinese food in russian hill, but sun kwong is one of them.  there's no great decor or ambience, which is a sure sign of any decent chinese restaurant.  the woman who works there is super nice...soo nice that i ended up ordering an extra entree to go when all i wanted was soup.  prices are cheap,  so the extra dish didn't put a crazy dent in my wallet either.
author: Helen T.

description: It's really worth it . For less than 15$ we had a huge dinner my husband and I. We went the family offer for two and we wished we were more hungry. It's not a fancy place but you know  you will it something tasty and quickly.
author: mia m.
